newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong market on pre-handover rollercoaster.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong market on pre-handover rollercoaster.

text.p: Hong Kong's stock market went into the last week before Chinese rule on a rollercoaster, soaring to new heights on Monday and quickly plunging again.
With five working days to go before Britain hands Hong Kong back to China, the Hang Seng Index gained more than one percent to reach a record new high of 15,322.33 shortly after opening.

The gains were then promptly wiped out by profit-taking. But analysts said the market, which made its biggest-ever one-day gain on Friday, was still strong with money flowing in from mainland China to the world's seventh largest trading economy.
Outgoing governor Chris Patten said Britain was handing back Hong Kong to China in superb economic shape -- and warned his successor Tung Chee-hwa not to be an autocrat.
"In Hong Kong, there is no one who has absolute power," Britain's 28th and last governor told the Chinese-language paper Ming Pao in an interview marking the end of 156 years of colonial rule.
After their summit in Denver, the Group of Seven industrialised nations also called on China to maintain its commitment to respect Hong Kong's freedoms.
"The whole world will be watching very carefully," said President Bill Clinton.
Business was bullish as the capitalist enclave of 6.4 million people -- widely hailed as the world's freest marketplace -- prepared to be taken over by the communist giant.

An overwhelming 92 percent of executives polled at a Far Eastern Economic Review conference said they were positive. The survey also revealed that maintaining a democratic system was ranked as the least important factor for Hong Kong's economic well-being.

Larry Yung, the influential "red princeling" who runs CITIC Pacific -- the Hong Kong branch of China's official foreign trading arm -- warned Beijing that Hong Kong's economic miracle would end if China abandoned the separate development formula planned for the next 50 years.
"If Beijing were to try to move the system in China to Hong Kong, then 'one country, two systems' would be gone and that would be the end of Hong Kong," he told Time magazine.
Former shipping magnate Tung extended an olive branch to democrat activists who have mocked him as a Beijing puppet and promised to stage handover protests.
"I hope those in the democratic camp will move on with us," Tung told the South China Morning Post.
But he has stressed that new laws restricting demonstrations would take effect from the minute the territory becomes part of China on the stroke of midnight on June 30.
The Royal Yacht Britannia sailed into Hong Kong harbour on a grey and wet Monday morning, marking the beginning of the end of the last major British colony.
Patten sails off aboard Britannia after the handover with heir-to-the-throne Prince Charles.
Organisers promised "there won't be a dry eye in the house" at next Monday's sunset ceremony that lowers the curtain on British rule east of Suez.
